Description: Hartford Financial Services Group, Inc. agreed to pay $55 million to settle allegations that it  misrepresented and failed to disclose to fund shareholders and the funds' Boards of Directors its use of fund assets to pay for the marketing and distribution of Hartford mutual funds and annuities.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 52411: Direct Life, Health, and Medical Insurance Carriers
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: The U.S. Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control announced a $271,815 settlement with Navigators Insurance Company to settle potential civil liability for 48 apparent violations of the Foreign Assets Control Regulations.

Description: The Hartford Financial Services Group agreed to pay $1.3 million in settlement of allegations it colluded with other reinsurance providers and a reinsurance broker to increase costs with anticompetitive schemes.
Hartford Fire agreed to pay $2.1 million to settle multistate litigation regarding its use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.

Description: Hartford Financial agreed to pay $115 million to Connecticut, Illinois and New York to settle allegations of improper fictitious quoting, steering of insurance business and allowance of improper market-timing in variable annuity products.
Info Source: Madigan: Settlement Reached with Hartford; Investigation Uncovered Unlawful Fictitious Quoting Scheme, States News Service, July 23, 2007 (via Nexis).

Description: The attorneys general of Connecticut and New York announced that a leading insurance firm would pay $20 million in restitution and fines to resolve an investigation of fraud in connection with the sale of group annuities.
